intro: Abutilon virgatum var. tomentosum, commonly known as the velvetleaf abutilon, is a deciduous shrub native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its fuzzy, velvety leaves that give it a distinctive tactile quality. The plant produces showy, lantern-shaped flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and red, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its stems are often covered in fine hairs, contributing to its overall textured appearance. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and is often used in ornamental gardening for its unique foliage and floral display.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon virgatum var. tomentosum is primarily native to the southeastern United States, including parts of Florida, Georgia, and the Carolinas. It is also found in the coastal regions of the Gulf Coast and along the Atlantic coast. This plant thrives in sandy, well-drained soils and is commonly found in coastal dunes and maritime hammocks. It is often associated with disturbed or open habitats such as roadsides and forest edges. Its native range extends into parts of the Caribbean, including the Bahamas and the Lesser Antilles.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon virgatum var. tomentosum was mainly introduced to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It is commonly found in moist, disturbed areas such as roadsides and stream banks. This plant is considered invasive in some regions due to its rapid growth and ability to outcompete native vegetation. It thrives in temperate climates with moderate rainfall. Its hairy leaves and showy flowers make it a distinctive and sometimes ornamental species.
